page.title: 18FARMING
page.content: It is a well-known fact that some 1% of all farmland in Britain is lost annually to urban growth. This can be well demonstrated in the Derby area. Within the suburbs themselves there are buildings which can be identified as former farm houses now surrounded not with fields but with rows of terraced and semi-detached housing. The process is still continuing, as schools, playing fields and new housing estates swallow up land adjacent to the city both in Chellaston and Alvaston. Farmers are influenced by the economic pressures but also by the problems of farming near to new estates. Animals are disturbed, crops damaged, litter dropped, fences broken down.Such problems are aggravated when footpathe provide short cuts to other villages or country parks.
